description.back: Controls posture, movement, and the sense of balance.
Processes sensory information from the whole body, such as information about pain, touch, and pressure.
The most primitive part of the brain, connects the brain to the spinal cord and controls simple reflexes, heart rate, respiration, and blood pressure.
Located deep inside the brain, responsible for learning, memory, and emotional behavior.
The exchange of information between the axon of one neuron and the dendrites of another neuron through the release of chemicals into the synapse.
Cells responsible for carrying information throughout the body by both electrical and chemical impulses, composed of a cell body, dendrites, and an axon.
A protective covering that insulates the axons of many neurons, helping nerve signals travel faster, farther, and more efficiently.

name: What are the main parts of the brain mentioned in the module?

description.front: What are the main parts of the brain mentioned in the module?
description.back: The main parts of the brain are the cerebral cortex, hypothalamus, cerebellum, brain stem, and limbic system.
Special molecules found on the dendrites and cell bodies of neurons that convert the information from neurotransmitters into chemical or electrical signals.

name: What are the lobes of the cerebral cortex?

description.front: What are the lobes of the cerebral cortex?
description.back: The lobes of the cerebral cortex are frontal, parietal, occipital, and temporal.
Chemicals released into the synapse that bind to receptors on the dendrite of the second neuron, initiating the transmission of information.
The hypothalamus regulates body temperature, hunger, and thirst.

name: What functions are controlled by the cerebellum?

description.front: What functions are controlled by the cerebellum?
description.back: The cerebellum controls posture, movement, and the sense of balance.
The space between the axon of one neuron and the dendrites of another neuron.
Links the nervous system to the endocrine system by producing and releasing hormones, and regulates body temperature, hunger, and thirst.

name: What are the two main parts of the brain stem and their functions?

description.front: What are the two main parts of the brain stem and their functions?
description.back: The two main parts of the brain stem are the pons, which controls sleep, awakening, and dream onset, and the medulla, which controls heart rate, respiration, and blood pressure.

name: Which parts of the limbic system are mentioned and their functions?

description.front: Which parts of the limbic system are mentioned and their functions?
description.back: The hippocampus, mainly responsible for learning and memory, and the amygdala, which plays an important role in emotional behavior, are mentioned as parts of the limbic system.

name: What are the three main parts of a neuron?

description.front: What are the three main parts of a neuron?
description.back: A neuron consists of the cell body, dendrites, and an axon.

name: What is the role of the myelin sheath?

description.front: What is the role of the myelin sheath?
description.back: The myelin sheath covers the axons of many neurons, insulates them, and helps messages travel faster, farther, and more efficiently.
Neurotransmission is the exchange of information between the axon of one neuron and the dendrites of another through the release of chemicals into the space between them.
The largest part of the human brain, making up more than 75 percent of the organ, controlling thinking, perception, and understanding language.
Processes visual information coming into the brain.
A bundle of fibers that serves as the bridge between the brain's two hemispheres, facilitating communication between them.
Responsible for initiating and coordinating motor movements and higher cognitive skills, such as problem solving and thinking.
In charge of making sense of auditory information from the environment.
